Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Situation2: The weekly group meditation meets for an hour today, and I am the leader of the session.
Story: This afternoon, my mother called me into the kitchen, her voice warm but insistent. “You’ll lead the ancestor ceremony tonight,” she said, placing the old incense holder in my hands. “It’s important for our family, for our traditions.” I nodded, feeling the weight of her expectation settle on my shoulders. I know how much this means to her, to all of us—honoring our ancestors, keeping our family’s rituals alive. But as I looked at the clock, my heart tightened. In just an hour, I’m supposed to guide the weekly meditation at the temple. As the group leader, everyone relies on me to create a space of calm and mindfulness, to help them find peace in their busy lives. I can’t imagine letting them down, but I also can’t bear the thought of disappointing my family. My mind races, torn between the quiet sanctuary of the temple and the warmth of my family’s traditions. The incense in my hand feels heavier with every passing minute, and I can’t escape the feeling that, no matter what I choose, a part of me will be left behind.
